BC-PHOTO-BUDGET-NYT 
   ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving Thursday, 12/22/99. Photo
clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's
PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Phot
Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos
on Newscom at 305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual
purchases by calling (888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT38) PANAMA CITY - Dec. 23, 1999 - ADV. FOR SUN, DEC. 26 --
PANAMA-CANAL-2-COX -- Fresh water enters the Panama Canal in
Gaillard Cut. Panama's torrential rains provide enough water that
the locks run on gravity flow, without pumps to move the ships.
Control of the canal is officially transferred
to Panama from the United States on December 31. (Levette
Bagwell/Cox News Service)

   (NYT37) PANAMA CITY - Dec. 23, 1999 - ADV. FOR SUN, DEC. 26 --
PANAMA-CANAL-1-COX -- Carrying his purchases from a local market
earlier this month, a
man walks past a mural that depicts the transfer of the Panama
Canal to the nation. Control of the canal is officially transferred
to Panama from the United States on December 31. (Levette
Bagwell/Cox News Service) LITE

   (NYT36) MOSCOW - Dec. 23, 1999 - MOSCOW-SANTA -- Grandfather
Frost, the
embodiment of Russia's holiday season, helps a store sell its
leather coats in
downtown Moscow. But Santa Claus is moving in on his territory.
(James Hill/The
New York Times)

   (NYT34) UNDATED -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
NY-CENTURY-EVENTS-3 -- Malcolm S. Forbes redefined wretched excess
in 1970, when he flew hundreds of close friends, like Elizabeth
Taylor (center) and Beverly Sills (right), to Morocco for his 70th
birthday. Parties are to be measured by the column inches of
ritualized contumely printed by newspapers, including this one,
sking over the frivolity of the privileged classes. (The Boston
Globe)

   (NYT33) UNDATED -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
CLARKS-RAP-FASHION-2 -- Clarks' imitators could fill a couple of
shelves. From top, styles
by Lugz, Phat Farm, Tsubo, Duffer and Paul Smith. (Tony
Cenicola/The New York Times)

   (NYT32) UNDATED -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
CLARKS-RAP-FASHION-1 -- The Clarks Desert Boot, which traces its
origins to World War II. Clarks have periodically been part of a
uniform for rebellious youth since the mid-1960s, when British mods
on their Vespa motor scooters paired straight-leg pants with the
soft, ankle-high boots with two sets of eyelets. (Tony Cenicola/The
New York Times)

   (NYT31) LONDON -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
MEMBERS-ONLY-CLUBS -- The contemporary artwork amid 18th-century
detail is one sign that Home House is not your usual London
members' club. The presence of women is another. (Carlos
Lopez-Barillas/The New York Times)

   (NYT30) NEW YORK -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
NY-CENTURY-EVENTS-2-B&W -- Bianca Jagger sits in for Lady Godiva at
her 1978 birthday party at Studio 54. The picture flashed round the
tabloid world. Baryshnikov and Mick Jagger were dancing together,
and disco never reached greater heights. (Rose Hartman/The Boston
Globe)

   (NYT29) NEW YORK -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
NY-CENTURY- EVENTS-1-B&W -- Guests slip into a side entrance of the
Plaza for Truman Capote's Black and White Ball in 1966, a landmark
stew of politics, society and
literature, including detectives from ``In Cold Blood.'' When it
comes to memorable parties, success is in direct proportion to the
outrage produced. Nothing, that is, succeeds like wretched excess.
(Barton Silverman/The New York
Times) LITE

   (NYT28) UNDATED - Dec. 23, 1999 - SHOPPING-FEATURE -- A street
corner in
Manhattan's Herald Square bustles with activity Thursday as some
shoppers try to hail a cab while juggling their packages on the
second to the last day before Christmas. (Chang W. Lee/ The New
York Times)

   (NYT27) PROVIDENCE, R.I. - Dec. 23, 1999 -- MALL-SCHOOL-2 -- A
potential
customer looks through the window as Saveth Sum prepares chocolate
macaroons at
the Godiva Chocolate store in the Providence Place Mall earlier
this week. Sum is working in the store as part of her studies at
Providence Place Academy. If retail is war, then the students of
the academy are the first cadets in the country to have their boot
camp on the field of battle. The academy, a fledgling alternative
public high school oriented toward business training, is believed
to be the first vocational high school in the nation to be based in
a working mall. (Evan Richman/The New York Times)

   (NYT26) PROVIDENCE, R.I. - Dec. 23, 1999 -- MALL-SCHOOL-1 --
Naomi Wierzbick, a student at Providence Place Academy, watches
customers shop for her marketing internship at the Providence Place
Academy earlier this week. If retail is war, then the students of
Providence Place Academy are the first cadets in the country to
have their boot camp on the field of battle. The academy, a
fledgling alternative public high school oriented toward business
training, is believed to be the first vocational high school in the
nation to be based in a working mall. (Evan Richman/The New York
Times)

   (NYT25) VIENNA, Virg. - Dec. 23, 1999 -- BUCHANAN-REFORM -- Tim
Haley, policy director for Pat Buchanan, running for the Reform
party's presidential nomination, meets with Bay Buchanan, the
candidate's sister and battle-hardened
campaign manager, at Buchanan's headquarters on Friday. With 21
states already having Reform party lines on their presidential
ballot, Buchanan's grinding task, carried out in the shadow of the
major parties' cycle of primary contests, is to impress Reform
loyalists by organizing the other 29 states for his candidacy.
(Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

   (NYT24) NEW YORK - Dec. 23, 1999 -- BANKS-VENTURE-CAPITAL --
Jeffrey Walker, a venture capitalist with Chase Capital Partners,in
his office earlier this week. A few banks, notably Chase and Wells
Fargo, have had successful venture arms for years. But others have
little experience with the hyper- competition of Silicon Valley.
(Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

   (NYT23) BETHLEHEM, West Bank - Dec. 23, 1999 -
BETHLEHEM-CHRISTMAS-2-- A
priest leaves the Church of the Nativity through its only door
which leads to Manger Square on Thursday. The church, erected over
where it is believed Jesus of Nazareth was born, is expecting
hundreds of pilgrims for midnight Mass on Saturday. (Rina
Castelnuovo/The New York Times)

   (NYT22) BETHLEHEM, West Bank - Dec. 23, 1999 -
BETHLEHEM-CHRISTMAS -- An
Italian nun kisses the spot where the faithful believe Jesus of
Nazareth was born Thursday in the Church of the Nativity. The city,
just five miles south of
Jerusalem, was under British and then Jordanian control until
Israel captured it in 1967. The following years saw it beset by
tens of thousands of Palestinian refugees. In 1995, Israel
transferred control of the city to the Palestinian Authority, run
by Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat. Still bracketed
by Israeli roadblocks, Bethlehem is one of more than 100 sectors of
the West Bank that have been turned over to Palestinian control.
(Rina Castelnuovo/The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT21) NEW YORK - Dec. 23, 1999 -- NY-CREW-EDUC-2 -- Mayor Rudy
Guiliani of New York speaks with Rudy Crew, chancellor of the Board
of Education, during
an ceremonies opening the Bayard Rustin High School for Humanities
in March, 1999. A sharply-divided board voted Thursday not to
extend Crew's contract, heralding the end of Crew's sometimes rocky
tenure as the head of the nation's largest public school system.
(Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

   (NYT20) NEW YORK - Dec. 23, 1999 -- NY-CREW-EDUC -- Rudy Crew,
chancellor of the New York City Board of Education, during a 1998
meeting of the board. A sharply-divided board voted Thursday not to
extend Crew's contract, heralding the end of Crew's sometimes rocky
tenure as the head of the nation's largest public school system.
(Andrea Mohin/The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT19) LOS ANGELES - Dec. 23, 1999 -- CLINTON-PARDONS -- U.S.
Navy seaman Freddie Meeks in 1944, left, and in 1999 at his home.
President Clinton issued his annual holiday pardons on Thursday,
among them one for Meeks who was court- martialed for mutiny when
he and others refused to load live ammunition following deadly 1944
explosions on two transport ships. (Monica Almeida, right/The New
York Times)

   (NYT18) BALTIMORE -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
BIZ-MALLS- BECKER --Gordon Becker and his son, Eric, at the
Baltimore showroom of the Becker Group, which provides seasonal
displays for shopping malls. Eric, 37, and his brother, Doug, 33,
now advise their father on new ideas for the business. (Marty
Katz/The New York Times)

   (NYT17) NEW YORK -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
INVEST- EMERGE-MARKETS -- Abby Joseph Cohen, the Goldman Sachs
market strategist who has long been one of Wall Street's leading
bulls, is looking toward more modest
market gains next year. ``I am trying to come up with a forecast
that is not on the extreme end of the bell curve,'' she says. ``I
want a forecast that we are comfortable with achieving.'' (Angel
Franco/The New York Times)

   (NYT16) LAS VEGAS -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
ABOUT- CARS-VOLVO -- Volvo's compact S40 sedan directly challenges
the Audi A4 and BMW
323i, and it offers a Swedish alternative to cars like the Toyota
Camry. By next fall, the auto maker - which was bought by Ford this
year - will have completed a three-year overhaul of its entire
American lineup. (The New York Times)

   (NYT15) SINGAPORE -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
ASEAN- ECON-2 -- The lobby of an office of the Daiwa Bank of Japan
is vacant as the bank has scaled back its operations in Singapore.
Employees of Nippon Express in Singapore, left, say they have been
moving more families back to Japan. (The
New York Times)

   (NYT14) SINGAPORE -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
ASEAN- ECON-1 -- A worker waits for business at a Singapore karaoke
bar, where Japanese customers are scarce. In the first half of
1999, Japanese banks pulled
nearly $10 billion in loans from the region, part of a rollback
that has sucked
$108 billion out of Southeast Asia since 1995 and cut Japan's share
of foreign lending here from more than half to less than one-third.
(The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT13) UNDATED -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
BIZ-FRAUD-
LAW -- To run its investigative office in Chicago, Deloitte &
Touche hired Don M. Svendson, who had a 26-year career with the
Royal Canadian Mounted Police. ``There's no end in sight to the
rise in embezzlement, executive malfeasance and
money laundering,'' says Svendson, 50. (The New York Times)

   (NYT12) NEW YORK -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
BIZ-FIVE-
QUESTIONS-B&W -- Jim Strupp sees regional appeal in the small
breweries his company is buying. ``Well, number one, we don't want
to take on the giants,'' he says. ``We think there's an opportunity
for a small regional brewery to be successful, if the costs are
very competitive and if we focus on niche marketing.'' (The New
York Times)

   (NYT11) BOSTON - Dec. 23, 1999 -- CHRISTMAS-ADJUSTMENTS --
Brother John
Maganzini, a Franciscan friar, adjusts the lights on the Christmas
tree on the
second floor of St. Anthony's shrine. The shrine has been holding
Masses throughout the advent season in preparation for Christmas.
(Janet Knott/The Boston Globe)

   (NYT10) BOSTON - Dec. 23, 1999 - TEDDY-GIVEAWAY-BOS -- Teddy
bears are unloaded at Children's Hospital on Thursday. The Four
Seasons Hotel gave away hundreds of teddy bears to children who
have to spend their Christmas in the hospital. (David L. Ryan/The
Boston Globe) LITE

   (NYT9) NEW YORK -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- INTERNATIONAL-STYLE-4 --
Kivi Sotamaa, a Finnish architect, near the Chase Building (in the
background) on Park Avenue. To a surprising number of architects
and city-lovers, the so- called Park Avenue Corridor in Manhattan
is the architectural heart of the 20th
century. (Jeffery A. Salter/The New York Times)

   (NYT8) NEW YORK -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- INTERNATIONAL-STYLE-3 -- The
grand
boulevard of International Style office towers on Park Avenue,
looking north. To a surprising number of architects and
city-lovers, the so-called Park Avenue
Corridor in Manhattan is the architectural heart of the 20th
century. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

   (NYT7) NEW YORK -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- INTERNATIONAL-STYLE-2 --
David Childs, who has been hired to restore the exterior of Lever
House and design new offices, outside the building on Park Avenue.
To a surprising number of architects and city-lovers, the so-called
Park Avenue Corridor in Manhattan is the architectural heart of the
20th century.(Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

   (NYT6) NEW YORK -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- INTERNATIONAL-STYLE-1 --
Philip Johnson surrounded by some young Turks of design: from left,
Lindy Roy, Jeffrey
Kipnis, Nanako Umemoto, Jesse Reiser, Lise Anne Couture, Hani
Rashid and Kivi Sotamaa. To a surprising number of other architects
and city-lovers, the so- called Park Avenue Corridor in Manhattan
is the architectural heart of the 20th
century. (Jeffery A. Salter/The New York Times)

   (NYT5) NEW YORK -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
INVEST- BROADWAY-SHOWS -- This musical, ``Swing'', cost $5.6
million to produce, including $1.5 million gathered from numerous
individual investors. Attendance on the Great White Way may be
booming, but those willing to put money into what
remains a high-risk, low-return investment are still hard to come
by. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

   (NYT4) ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN.,
DEC. 26 -- BIZ-PROFILE-LOVEMAN -- Gary W. Loveman, the chief
operating officer of Harrah's, at its Showboat Casino in Atlantic
City. He says his industry can grow by getting more business from
existing operations. (Laura Pedrick/The New York Times)

   (NYT3) MOUNT KISCO, N.Y. -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC.
26 --
BEARS-MARKET-3 -- David A. Levy, from his office at the Levy
Institute Forecasting Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Center is
funded by Leon Levy, a founder of Oppenheimer & Co. The Levys worry
that a market break will cause consumers with a falling net worth
to spend less, shrink corporate profits and leave the economy with
a what they contend has been too much capital investment. (Joyce
Dopkeen/The New York Times)

   (NYT2) NEW YORK -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
BEARS- MARKET-2 -- James Grant, editor of a subscription-only
industry newsletter, Grant's Interest Rate Observer, in the
company's Wall Street office. ``I am a skeptical person,'' says the
former Barron's columnist. He calls himself ``the world's leading
authority on where the stock market's not going.'' (Elizabeth
Lippman/The New York Times)

   (NYT1) NEW YORK -- Dec. 23, 1999 -- ADV. FOR SUN., DEC. 26 --
BEARS- MARKET-1 -- James S.Chanos, president, Kynikos Associates,
in his Manhattan office. Chanos says the market's strength is
propping up many overpriced issues. (Jack Manning/The New York
Times)

   The New York Times
